hotspots.label: Earthworm Body
hotspots.fact: Earthworms are living organisms that have long, tube-shaped bodies made of many segments, or rings. Each segment helps the earthworm move and bend as it tunnels through soil. This is called **segmentation** — that's when an animal's body is divided into separate rings or sections that help it move and function.

vocabulary.definition: When an animal's body is divided into separate rings or sections that help it move and do its job.

hotspots.label: Earthworm Habitat
hotspots.fact: This earthworm is on grass and in soil, which is its natural habitat where it lives and finds food. Earthworms help break down dead plants and leaves, making the soil rich and healthy for new plants to grow. This is called **decomposition** — that's when dead things break down and turn into nutrients that help new life grow.

vocabulary.definition: The place where a living thing makes its home and finds food, water, and shelter.

hotspots.label: Earthworm Skin
hotspots.fact: Earthworms have moist skin that helps them breathe, because they don't have lungs like we do! Their skin must stay wet so oxygen can pass through it into their body. If an earthworm's skin dries out, it cannot survive.

vocabulary.definition: The way living things take in oxygen and use it to stay alive and have energy to move and grow.

hotspots.label: Grass & Ecosystem
hotspots.fact: The grass in this image is part of an ecosystem with the earthworm — they depend on each other! Earthworms loosen the soil so grass roots can grow deeper, and dead grass becomes food for earthworms. This is called a **food chain** — that's when living things depend on each other for food and survival.

vocabulary.definition: A group of living things and their environment all working together, where they need each other to survive.
